longDescription:
The Flaming Spear That Never Missed Its Mark The Spear of Lugh (Gae Assail or Areadbhair) is one of the Four Treasures of the Tuatha
                    De Danann, the magical race who ruled Ireland in the mythological age. This fiery spear
                    was brought from the city of Gorias by the Tuatha De Danann when they came to Ireland,
                    and it was wielded by Lugh Lamhfada (Lugh of the Long Arm), the master of all skills.

extendedContent.title: Description and Nature
extendedContent.content:
The Spear of Lugh (Gae Assail or Areadbhair) is one of the Four Treasures of the Tuatha
                    De Danann, the magical race who ruled Ireland in the mythological age. This fiery spear
                    was brought from the city of Gorias by the Tuatha De Danann when they came to Ireland,
                    and it was wielded by Lugh Lamhfada (Lugh of the Long Arm), the master of all skills.
                
                
                    The spear was so bloodthirsty that it had to be kept submerged in a cauldron of water
                    (or sometimes poppy juice) when not in battle, lest it burn down the city around it
                    with its perpetual flame. When Lugh took it to battle, it would flash through the
                    air with the speed of lightning, and no enemy could stand against it.

extendedContent.title: Mythology and Legend
extendedContent.content:
Lugh of the Long Arm
                
                    Lugh was the greatest warrior of the Tuatha De Danann, a god of light, skill, and victory.
                    Called Lamhfada ("Long Arm") for his prowess with the throwing spear, he was master of
                    every art and craft. When he came to Tara seeking admission to the court, he claimed to
                    practice every skill, and proved it against all challengers.
                

                The Second Battle of Mag Tuired
                
                    The spear's most famous use was in the Second Battle of Mag Tuired, where the Tuatha De
                    Danann fought the Fomorians, a race of demonic giants. Lugh led the Tuatha De Danann
                    forces and, wielding his flaming spear, struck down Balor of the Evil Eye, the terrible
                    Fomorian king whose gaze could kill armies. With Balor's death, the Fomorians were
                    broken and driven from Ireland.

longDescription:
Claoimh Solais - The Sword of Light From Which None Could Escape The Sword of Nuada, known as Claoimh Solais (the "Sword of Light"), is one of the Four
                    Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann. Brought from the mythical city of Findias when the
                    Tuatha De Danann came to Ireland, this sword was the weapon of their first king, Nuada
                    Airgetlam ("Silver Hand").

extendedContent.title: Description and Nature
extendedContent.content:
The Sword of Nuada, known as Claoimh Solais (the "Sword of Light"), is one of the Four
                    Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann. Brought from the mythical city of Findias when the
                    Tuatha De Danann came to Ireland, this sword was the weapon of their first king, Nuada
                    Airgetlam ("Silver Hand").
                
                
                    The sword's most terrifying property was its inescapability: once the sword was drawn
                    from its sheath, no enemy could flee from it, and no one could resist its deadly stroke.
                    As a blade of pure light, it represented justice and righteous warfare, the legitimate
                    violence of the king in defense of his people.

extendedContent.title: Nuada and the Four Treasures
extendedContent.content:
King Nuada
                
                    Nuada was the first king of the Tuatha De Danann in Ireland. During the First Battle
                    of Mag Tuired against the Fir Bolg, he lost his hand and had to relinquish kingship,
                    as Celtic law required a king to be physically perfect. The physician-god Dian Cecht
                    fashioned him a silver hand, but he was not restored to kingship until Miach (Dian
                    Cecht's son) gave him a hand of flesh.
                

                The Four Treasures United
                
                    Together, the Four Treasures represented complete sovereignty over Ireland:
                
                
                    Stone of Fal: Legitimacy - screamed under the true king
                    Sword of Nuada: Justice - from which none could escape
                    Spear of Lugh: Victory - which never lost a battle
                    Cauldron of Dagda: Prosperity - which satisfied all
